qas.question: What agency oversees public schools in North Carolina?

answers.text: North Carolina Department of Public Instruction

qas.question: Who holds most legal authority for making education policy?
What year did the boards chairman become the Chief Executive officer of public schools?
How many public school systems does North Carolina have?
What is the largest school system in North Carolina?

context: Elementary and secondary public schools are overseen by the <a0_0>North Carolina Department of Public Instruction<a0_0/>. The North Carolina Superintendent of Public Instruction is the secretary of the North Carolina State Board of Education, but <a1_0>the board<a1_0/>, rather than the superintendent, holds most of the legal authority for making public education policy. In <a2_0>2009<a2_0/>, the board's chairman also became the "chief executive officer" for the state's school system. North Carolina has <a3_0>115<a3_0/> public school systems, each of which is overseen by a local school board. A county may have one or more systems within it. The largest school systems in North Carolina are the <a4_0>Wake County Public School System<a4_0/>, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools, Guilford County Schools, Winston-Salem/Forsyth County Schools, and Cumberland County Schools. In total there are 2,425 public schools in the state, including 99 charter schools. North Carolina Schools were segregated until the Brown v. Board of Education trial and the release of the Pearsall Plan.
